DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Mobilize Troops, Call U.S. Invasion Serious Threat
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The leftist Sandinista government put its armed forces on maximum alert today, mobilized troops and tanks and called the U.S. invasion of Panama ``a serious threat to Nicaragua.'' Large howitzers were set up in the center of downtown Managua and Red Beret special forces in camouflage uniforms were posted at the international airport. President Daniel Orgega declared a ``state of national alert'' and asked for an urgent meeting of the U.N. Security Council. In New York, the Security Council agreed to meet in emergency session today. Ortega also sent messages to the Non-Aligned Movement and Pope John Paul II saying he was ``deeply concerned by the invasion of Panama.'' ``In addition to constituting a flagrant trampling of the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Panama, it is a threat to the peace and security of all Latin America, Central America and especially constitutes a serious threat to Nicaragua,'' Ortega said in a communique read on Voice of Nicaragua radio. The army was put on a ``state of combative general alert.'' The communique said that implied immediate deployment of land, sea and air combat units. Reserves and civilian militia also were called up. Reporters saw Soviet-made T-55 tanks moving through the capital. At least 20 howitzers were set up in the old shell of the city center, flattened in the 1972 earthquake and fires, and never rebuilt. ``When the world is demanding dialogue, peaceful solution of conflicts and renunciation of the threat and use of force ... actions like those that are causing destruction and death in our sister state of Panama threaten the security and precarious stability of the Central American region,'' said the communique. In declaring the state of alert, the government mentioned U.S. invasions of Nicaragua earlier this century and continuing confrontation over U.S.-supported Contra rebels in the past 10 years.
